unnormalised: Automotive News Flash: Decoding New Traffic Regulations for a Safer Bharat
normalised: Automotive News Flash: Decoding New Traffic Regulations for a Safer Bharat

unnormalised: Navigating India's bustling roads just got a little clearer. The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has announced updated traffic regulations, effective November 1st, aimed at improving road safety. Forget 'Deewar' dialogues; following the rules is the real hero act now!
normalised: Navigating India's bustling roads just got a little clearer. The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has announced updated traffic regulations, effective November first, aimed at improving road safety. Forget 'Deewar' dialogues; following the rules is the real hero act now!

unnormalised: Key changes include stricter penalties for distracted driving, especially mobile phone usage. Fines for first-time offenders could reach Rs. 5000. Enhanced regulations are also in place for lane discipline, with mandatory indicators and increased visibility requirements for heavy vehicles.
normalised: Key changes include stricter penalties for distracted driving, especially mobile phone usage. Fines for first-time offenders could reach rupee five thousand. Enhanced regulations are also in place for lane discipline, with mandatory indicators and increased visibility requirements for heavy vehicles.

unnormalised: The Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Delhi, in collaboration with the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI), is launching a nationwide awareness campaign, employing multilingual PSAs and educational materials. New speed limits are being enforced on the Yamuna Expressway, with a maximum of 100 km/h for cars and 60 km/h for trucks. Remember, safety comes first! Familiarize yourself with the new rules to avoid hefty fines and contribute to a safer driving environment for all. These regulations are applicable nationwide, from the streets of Mumbai to the highways of Himachal Pradesh.
normalised: The Indian Institute of Technology (I I T) Delhi, in collaboration with the National Highways Authority of India (N H A I), is launching a nationwide awareness campaign, employing multilingual P S A s and educational materials. New speed limits are being enforced on the Yamuna Expressway, with a maximum of one hundred kilometer per hour for cars and sixty kilometer per hour for trucks. Remember, safety comes first! Familiarize yourself with the new rules to avoid hefty fines and contribute to a safer driving environment for all. These regulations are applicable nationwide, from the streets of Mumbai to the highways of Himachal Pradesh.
